sci, with upwards of 800 slaves on board, almost

her in their boats, and the Iphigena took posses

feeling which it ects, it ought Of itself to induce
every European government to take ettectual mea-

the slave trade appearing to diminish the reverse
is, believe, the fact; for it is seen with fearless
impudence establishing itself throughout immense
territories, in open defiance of every restraint,
particularly by the subjects of France, Spain, and
Portugal, whose ships engaged in it are numerous
beyond belief"

Sir-!iaving accidentally come in possession of
the Albany Observer Of the 9th ut. wherein found
contained the substance of four letters, written by
the committee who had assembled together
for the purpose ofobtaining some information rela-
tive to the affair of Morgan-and as the said com
mitee have thought proper to lay before the world
part of the clrcumstantal evidence obtained at
their general meeting, which certainly goes far to
impcate some persons who, perhaps, never heard
Of Morgan until after the bloody tragedy was all
overland as believe ! am the person alluded to,
as being the author Of such. information, hereby
feel myself obligated to most soemnly declare that
part OF the reports which are said to have been
taken from said letters are utterly talse-and that
part which aludes to Mr.. Chaplin, of Buffalo. as
being in any manner concerned in the murder of
Morgan, was certainly made without any regard
to truth.


And also they had no Just grounds to make the
following statements, viz: That Lodge of British
masons was ealled that Mr.. Brant was sent for !.
that Morgan was taken to Mr. Ms house !:
that two or more masons from Niagara we're pre.
sent at the meeting, &c.--Ihe whole Of these
statements totally deny as being the author.-
Yet that number of the committee did receive in
substance the whole account, (except that mart
which aludes to MIR. Chapin,) from some source.
have no doubt, but it come not from me. That
Morgan was butchered at Niagara, have no doubt.
but by whom do not pretend to say, and believe
that the man alluded to as being my informant,
knew no more of Morgan than the man in The moon,
The probably has heard of both.)


my reasons for believing that Morgan met his
fate as | have described above, | gave 10 tbe com.
mttee, but had no reason to believe that thev
would unnecessarily, lay it before the world d,
point out me as being the bul~ark of their proof
conceive myself to be highly imposed upon by
the committee, as they have done every th;ne =
their power to excite spleen against me il the
breasts OF those who would be pleased to snothe,
me late OF Morgan. do not censure the whole
body, for presume the majority knew notb;no mtue
about what was to take place

THE LETTER.
From the Niagara Cleaner, March 10.

MoRoAN's BooK.-We submit the following let
ter received this morning, with single remark,
that the closing phrase F." inundated upon the altar
of Masonic vengeance" is Of too sweepnga char
acter to be just.


BATAVIA, March IL, 1927.
TO the Editors Of the Statesman


Gentlemen-Having seem your paper OF the
Sd inst. statement Of a Chancery suit instituted
against some person persons in the city Of New
York, for the publication Of the !" Illustrations of
Masonry" to which am made party in the pros
ecution, desire you to state, that have not au-
thorised any such suit neither do consider my
self empowered so to do. Whoever has made use
Of my name in this suit, has done it without my
knowledge or adyisement. If there is any right
in the pro ,,rty above mentioned, conceive that
right to be vested in Mrs. Lucinda Morgan, the
wife Of the late Capt William Morgan. / use the
term late, as have no reason to doubt that he has
been inundated upon the Altar Of Masonic ven
geance. am, &c. %. G. MILLER.

AT a late hour last night, this anxiously looked
for letter came to hand. 1t adds another to the
many contradictions elected by thu Lewiston Con-
ventlon " Letters" and increases the fos around
things already too mysterious


The writers Of the letters said they had their in
formation from ga respectable mason of high de-
grse,' whom it would be difficult to impeach; and
now this same unimpeac.able gentleman comes out
and impeaches them, or one of them at least
Which to believe, let the reader say-we have bare
ly time to give the letter, with the remark that it
corroborates the statements Of the Chapins, excu-
patory of their deceased reatve--and also those of
Capt Brant, Mr.. Mcbride, &c.

DR.. TERRY'S LETTER.
From the Rochester Uaiiy .9drertiser.

VI which, sixteen were captured, having on board
2,4Sl slaves. These are facts substantiated by
unquestionabc proofs: and show, beyond the nos
sbiity OF doubt or contradiction, the preponde
rance Of France and Portugal in this tratfc.''


81 have not heard Of either American or Dutch
ships being on the coast engaged in the traffic Of
slaves; if they be at ALL il is not frequently, and
they are well covered; but am given to under
stand, from good authority, that in the Brazils,
especially at Bahia, ships papers are manufactured
with great facility. and that every vessel, which
puts to sea from that port, has generally French,
Spanish and Portuguese papers, colours, and cap.
tains."


"Their lardships being already acquainted with
the desperate attack made by the French and Span
ish slaye-ships in the river Bonny, in last APRIL,
on the boats Of this ship and the Myrmidon, which
ended in the capture Of the whole Of those ships
! feel it incumbent on me to mention combna.
ton said to be entered into, by the officers and
crews of the whole of those vessels, by which they
bound themselves to put to death every English
officer or man. belonging to the navy, who nigh,
fall into their hands on the coast Of Africa This


was in perfect unison with all and every thing
which the slavc-dealing has engendered. Of 4
similar nature was the agreement between the Spa


nish captains and their seamen the latter binding
themselves bindty to obey erery order, of whatere1
nature it might BE, and, in case of the vesse
being taken, not TO receive any wages. Such i
the depravity to which this slave trade debases thu
mind and the character Of the desperate bandit

Congress,-itis is subject Of lisapponmentandi
dissatisfaction, that Congress have adjourned, and
left the most important subjects of national policy
unsettled, and almost unattended to. The people
will not much longer endure such gross neglect Oh
their interests, and the waste Of their time and mo-
ney upon party, personal, and frivolous objects, 70
the detriment of the national wel-being. The ses'
sion just closed is monument of factlous violence,
which we would gladly forget, but which IN ITS e,
iects upon the country will be long remempeFea.'
The vital Importance Of several topics to be conSd
cred, led the community to expect that an exciu'
sive devotion to them would be given and that par
ty vrulence would yield tS their paramount conse'
quence-but whathas been the resultr Every en-
bryo politician has considered it his duty, and as
good fortune Of the people, that they should DC IN
formed of his valuable opinions upon the state o.
the republic, that he should deal out columns os
words seasoned with occasional truisus relative J,
the Importance Of honesty, purity Of elections anu
responsibility of public officers. Day after day 10.
been consumed in pupy and abortlye attempts ..
wit and eloquence. the lightnngs and thunoefS u
which were to sink into an early grave the "co
rupt administration" The Hall of the House =
Representatives has been made an arena Tor conoa'
OF passion and malice, and we find the Challenge =,
duel dated within IFS walls. We desire ~
to be querulous, but will not refrain from EXPIRE
sing an honest Indignation at such talthiesS eVu
duct on the part Of the peoples representatlses


The discussion Of resolution offered by MIR. oaln
ders, lnquirng why the Secretary Of State has =
ercsed the discretion confided to him by la@' =
designating the public printers, frivolous as u VA
has been suffered to consume portion OF eaca aa!
for nearly or quite third of the sesson-wh!iew, ",
bill regulating our commercial relations with 'ae y


ones OF Great Brtain-the subject OF dispu1e. ~ :.
tween Georgia and the United States, and ONE ,.s
momentous business, have been deferred to me ~
moment, and finally left undecided. exposing ~ y
country to the evils Of foreign quarre!s, ana y =
risk Of civil war. RI. Times

fellow, Friend. cid age has deformities emu,
OF its owndo not add TO it the deformts q siS''

We have Of late taken notice of the Morgan Affair."
although nothing else is thought Of or talked Of nhs
Western District 1t seems, however, that the governor
has consderel of sufficient consequence to transmit tie
following message


10 The Honorable the .qssen5ly.


GESTLEmrN The abduction Of WIIzrAa morgan being
an act of Unprecedented violence has justly excited
quuocsl reprobation and the apprehensons which are
entertained of his fate have produced general alarm at
anxiety Understanding that this subjet; under the con.
sideaton of your honorable body have thought proper
to communicate to you all the information my power re.
specting it; and this should have done before, had not

March II, 1897.

the present pass unnoticed. Perhaps his feeI;n,.
were wounded in manner that ought TO ;ns;fa
his conduct, and have only TO say, thai 'l tba..
who know me are best able to Judge how fr h,
statements are correct-and, for the lnformafn,
of those who do not know me, shall ONLY s,s
that even Mr.. Chaplin himself may discover tf,tiI
am not altogether SO destitute of rcsponsiblity :,
he has insnaated. w i

From the eighteenth and nineteenth reports OF the


Directors Of the .4frican Institution. read at their
Annual General Meetings, held in London on the
18th day of May, 1924, and on the 18th day Of
May, 1925.


Sir Robert Mends, whose subsequent loss the
directors and the country at large have deeply to
deplorc, in letter to the Admiralty, dated the
a6th June, 1922, makes the following important
observations -


mThe facts which have come to my knowledge.
in my opinion, 20 far to establish this point, that
the slaye-trade will never be suppressed till the
right of search be freely admitted, and every ship
found with slaves on board, or evidently engaged
in shaving, be liable to condemnation to such ship
Of war of any nation as may seize her" While
the slave trade lasts, man can readily convert
the person of another into cash. with much less
trouble than he could raise the hundredth part of
the value by labor" it gives rise to every sort Of
dissipation and icentiousness, leading the mind of
the more active of the natives away from the less
productive and slower pursuits of agriculture and
commerce. But "wherever the traffic in slaves
has been checked, the natives appear to have shown
a fair and reasonable desire Of cutivating the
natural productions Of their country. Our resi-
dent officers and merchants agree in asserting, that
these would be raised to any extent for which a
market could be found. presume this is as much
as could be expected from any people in state of
nature''


81 am informed, it is almost impossible to credit
the extent to which the slave trade has been carr-
ed on in the Bonny; there having actually sailed
from that river, between the months of July and
November last year, l26 slave vessels, eighty six
Of which were French. and the others Spaniards
"An immense number have already sailed this


year; and find many more expected, and have


asceItalned. from good authority, that they will


generally be under the French hag--that is, they


sail, with their slavng cargoes board, from the


Havana, to port IN France, and there clear out


come to this coast under the Iretence Of purchas-
ing palm oil and ivory, ship their slaves, and re.


turn to the coasts Of Cuba thus inhumanly laten'
! s.By The annexed boarding list, it will appear ia


their lordships. that, within very short period


the ships Of war on this coast have boarded forty


five vessels engaged in the slave trade viz

FROM tE2 ~. r. eommeTctnl .1drertlSer, .Mnrch 90


The excitement in the case Of Morgan contiuus,
to increase at the west, and where It will end m
mortal can tell. Meeting after meeting is held
and resolutions follow resolutions, each stl mors
violent and proscriptive than the other. The mail
of this morning brings US the following among
ther resolutions passed at Pultney, Steuben couD
ty:


Resolved, That zoe ioiH not hear anu irssma
son preach, unless said preacher shall refuse to meet
with any lodge Of Freemasons and shall openly
and boldly declare that the institution Of Masoury
is bad institution"


The presses in all parts Of the state, groan be-
meath the weight Of publications upon this subject
and yet they are denounced in public meetings,
prescribed, and threatened with loss Of patron
age. for their silence. Where is this excitement 70
end Are freemasons to be exterminated, because
a few unworthy men are suspected of having com.
mtted heinous crime, and for which those sus
pccted have been expelledl ? One would think from
the western papers, that the people are almost ripe
for general massacree Of the freemasons Tu
y those who have kindled this excitement be they
nasons or be they not, we fear they will yet have
much to answer for

that Morgan was taken to Mr. Ms house !:
that two or more masons from Niagara we're pre.

full articles.headline: EXTRACT
full articles.article:
From the eighteenth and nineteenth reports OF the


Directors Of the .4frican Institution. read at their
Annual General Meetings, held in London on the
18th day of May, 1924, and on the 18th day Of
May, 1925.


Sir Robert Mends, whose subsequent loss the
directors and the country at large have deeply to
deplorc, in letter to the Admiralty, dated the
a6th June, 1922, makes the following important
observations -


mThe facts which have come to my knowledge.
in my opinion, 20 far to establish this point, that
the slaye-trade will never be suppressed till the
right of search be freely admitted, and every ship
found with slaves on board, or evidently engaged
in shaving, be liable to condemnation to such ship
Of war of any nation as may seize her" While
the slave trade lasts, man can readily convert
the person of another into cash. with much less
trouble than he could raise the hundredth part of
the value by labor" it gives rise to every sort Of
dissipation and icentiousness, leading the mind of
the more active of the natives away from the less
productive and slower pursuits of agriculture and
commerce. But "wherever the traffic in slaves
has been checked, the natives appear to have shown
a fair and reasonable desire Of cutivating the
natural productions Of their country. Our resi-
dent officers and merchants agree in asserting, that
these would be raised to any extent for which a
market could be found. presume this is as much
as could be expected from any people in state of
nature''


81 am informed, it is almost impossible to credit
the extent to which the slave trade has been carr-
ed on in the Bonny; there having actually sailed
from that river, between the months of July and
November last year, l26 slave vessels, eighty six
Of which were French. and the others Spaniards
"An immense number have already sailed this


year; and find many more expected, and have


asceItalned. from good authority, that they will


generally be under the French hag--that is, they


sail, with their slavng cargoes board, from the


Havana, to port IN France, and there clear out


come to this coast under the Iretence Of purchas-
ing palm oil and ivory, ship their slaves, and re.


turn to the coasts Of Cuba thus inhumanly laten'
! s.By The annexed boarding list, it will appear ia


their lordships. that, within very short period


the ships Of war on this coast have boarded forty


five vessels engaged in the slave trade viz

The excitement in the case Of Morgan contiuus,
to increase at the west, and where It will end m
mortal can tell. Meeting after meeting is held
and resolutions follow resolutions, each stl mors
violent and proscriptive than the other. The mail
of this morning brings US the following among
ther resolutions passed at Pultney, Steuben couD
ty:


Resolved, That zoe ioiH not hear anu irssma
son preach, unless said preacher shall refuse to meet
with any lodge Of Freemasons and shall openly
and boldly declare that the institution Of Masoury
is bad institution"


The presses in all parts Of the state, groan be-
meath the weight Of publications upon this subject
and yet they are denounced in public meetings,
prescribed, and threatened with loss Of patron
age. for their silence. Where is this excitement 70
end Are freemasons to be exterminated, because
a few unworthy men are suspected of having com.
mtted heinous crime, and for which those sus
pccted have been expelledl ? One would think from
the western papers, that the people are almost ripe
for general massacree Of the freemasons Tu
y those who have kindled this excitement be they
nasons or be they not, we fear they will yet have
much to answer for
